A British television
documentary on the life of poet
Dylan Thomas will be filmed in
part on the Homewood Campus
the weekend of March 18. The
filming, which will take place at
Shriver Hall and other places on
campus, will use many Hopkins
students as extras.
Not only will the documentary
be the first on the life of the
famous Welsh poet, but it will
also be the biggest documentary
BBC/Wales has ever done. The
filming, which began in Wales
this week, will cover the entirety
of Thomas' life, from his
childhood in Wales to his death
in New York City.
Chronicling his life on both
sides of the Atlantic, the BBC is
trying to achieve complete
accuracy in depicting the times
of Thomas' life. In New York,
for example, they have obtained
the same reading strands that
were originally used in the
premiere reading of Under
Milkwood.

several other college campuses
because it was felt the
Homewood Campus today looks
like the sort of ivy-ish college one
would have found in the 19509s.

the Fifties; the sober conformity

college appearances met with

hysteria, and it is difficult today
to believe that large crowds of
students often massed in large
auditoriums to listen to and
cheer the Welsh poet.

Stretch was born too old for
school. The same could be said of most New Jersey boys.
Mentally they were never boys. Perhaps it was the
peculiar rarefied air, or some mysterious elixir in the
drinking supply. Either way, the partisans of neighboring
states refused to admit the superiority of the New Jersey
educational system. This haughty chauvinism instilled in
Hogan a certain sense of cosmopolitan injustice he could
never resolve.
However, young Hogan's mind was far removed from
such mawkish thoughts this balmy June's evening. He had

hooligan, and he regrettably retired to his sick bed. His
thoughts strayed to the lovely Beth Zvonchenko; he
sighed. High school was ending with a whimper, and not
the bang Ms. Zvonchenko had promised.
As Stretch began to snooze in his private nether world,
he sorted the driftwood on the Sandman's beach. High
school was a vile experience. Gym class in itself was the
most degrading torture inflicted upon an American in
peacetime. Stretch was an inept gamesplayer; a spasmodic

anxiety.

tolerance. Genitalia was no prdblem; he could hold his
own in that department. Rather, his nakedness was held
in abeyance by an irrational, somewhat perverse fear that
someone might espy a neglected, stray dingleberry

never told a soul.
